newsitem.title: GERMANY: Delors urges EMU protocol for economic cooperation.
newsitem.headline: Delors urges EMU protocol for economic cooperation.

text.p: Former Commission President Jacques Delors on Thursday called for the creation of a special protocol committing countries heading towards European currency union to cooperate on macro-economic policy.
Delors, speaking at a conference in Frankfurt, said such a commitment would help smooth out possible shocks within the European economy, while promoting growth and job creation.
He added that such a measure should not be feared as compromising the independence of a future European Central Bank, an issue that has caused apparent conflict among some European Union countries.

"The extent of cooperation has recently not been very encouraging. This is all the more reason to detail within a protocol the procedures and instruments for real agreement in macro-economic policies that is also compatible with the accords included in the stability pact," he said.
The stability pact, agreed late last year in Dublin, aims to ensure the stability of European economic conditions after monetary union, due 1999.

Delors said the laws and statutes relating to the German Bundesbank -- which among other things listed its goals as including price stability, full employment and sufficient growth -- showed that such a move was not necessarily incompatible with central bank independence.
"The same (goals) will apply to the European Central Bank, whose independence will naturally be completely respected," Delors, president of the European Commission between 1985-95, said.
"We could expect much from an economic union that was based both on the idea of macro-economic cooperation...and a completely independent European central bank," he added.
